facts.text: Balkrishna Purushottam Purani died on November 11, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: One Balkrishna Purushottam Purani died on November 11, 1947. He left behind him three widows and two daughters.

facts.text: Balkrishna Purushottam Purani left behind three widows named Indira, Ramluxmi and Prabhuluxmi and two daughters.

anchor.surface_text: He left behind him three widows and two daughters. The three widows were named Indira, Ramluxmi and Prabhuluxmi.

facts.text: The three widows inherited the estate of Balkrishna Purushottam Purani as legal heirs.

anchor.surface_text: These widows as legal heirs inherited the estate of the deceased, which companysisted of immovable properties situate in Ahmedabad, shares in Joint Stock Companies, money lying in deposit, and share in a registered firm.

facts.text: Estate consisted of immovable properties in Ahmedabad, shares in Joint Stock Companies, money in deposit, and share in a registered firm.

anchor.surface_text: These widows as legal heirs inherited the estate of the deceased, which companysisted of immovable properties situate in Ahmedabad, shares in Joint Stock Companies, money lying in deposit, and share in a registered firm.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer issued notices to the legal heirs of Balkrishna Purushottam Purani for assessment years 1950-51 and 1951-52.

anchor.surface_text: For the two assessment years 1950-51 and 1951-52  the companyresponding account years being the Sambat years 2005 and 2006  the Incometax Officer issued numberices to the legal heirs of Balkrishna Purushottam Purani.

facts.text: Returns were filed under heading 'Legal heirs of Balkrishna Purushottam Purani' or 'estate of Balkrishna', signed by Indira.

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant to those numberices, returns were filed under the heading, Legal heirs of Balkrishhna Purushottam Purani , in one case and in the name of the estate of Balkrishna in the other the status was shown as individual in one case and association of persons in -the other. They were signed by Indira, one of the three widows.

facts.text: For 1950-51, total income shown as Rs. 69,346 from property, share from firm, dividends, interest, ground rent.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment year 1950-51 the total income was shown as under- Rs. Property 11,011 Share from registered firm. 4,071 Dividends. 51,796 Interest 22,343 Ground rent 125 Total 69,346

facts.text: For 1951-52, total income shown as Rs. 92,426 from property, share from firm, dividends, interest on deposits, ground rent.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment year 1951-52, the total income was shown as- Rs. Property-. 10,879 Share from registered firm. 460 Dividends. 80,426 Interest on deposits 536 Ground rent 125 Total 92,426

facts.text: Income-tax Officer assessed as association of persons for both years.

anchor.surface_text: For both years the Income-tax Officer took the status of the assessee as an association of persons and on that footing made two assessment orders.

facts.text: Appeal to Appellate Assistant Commissioner raising points: assess widows separately not as AOP, and property income separate u/s 9(3).

anchor.surface_text: There was an appear to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner, and two of the points taken before him were a  that the three widows ought to have been assessed separately and number as an association of persons , and  b  that in any event, the income from property ought to have been assessed separately in the hands of the three widows by reason of the provisions in s. 9  3  of the Income-tax Act, 1922.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner rejected separate assessment of widows but accepted separate assessment of property income u/s 9(3).

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner rejected point  a  but accepted point  b .

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal held estate inherited by three widows as joint tenants, income assessed as AOP, s.9(3) not applicable.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal held that the entire estate of deceased Balkrishna Purushottam Purani was inherited and possessed by the three widows as joint tenants and its income was liable to be assessed in their hands in the status of an association of persons.

facts.text: Tribunal found widows did not exercise right to separate possession and managed property jointly.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal found that the widows in this case did number exercise their right to separate possession and enjoyment and they chose to manage the property jointly, each acting for herself and the others and receiving the income of the property which they were entitled to enjoy in equal shares.

facts.text: Assessee moved Tribunal for reference of questions to High Court, including question No.3 on AOP status.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee then moved the Tribunal to refer certain questions of law which arose out of its orders to the High Court of Bombay. The Tribunal referred four such questions, but we are number companycerned with only one of them, viz., question No. 3 which was in the following terms Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case the Tribunal was right in holding that the assessment made on the three widows of Balkrishna Purushottam Purani in the status of an association of persons is legal and valid in law ?

facts.text: Bombay High Court in I.T.R. Nos. 52 and 53 of 1955 held Tribunal erred, widows not AOP.

anchor.surface_text: Two references were made to the High Court in respect of the orders passed for two assessment years and they gave rise to Income-tax References Nos. 52 and 53 of 1955. ... The High Court held that the Tribunal was in error in companying to the companyclusion that the three widows companyld be assessed in the status of an association of persons with regard to the income which they earned as heirs of their deceased husband. Therefore, it answered question No. 3 in the negative.

facts.text: Commissioner obtained special leave to appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The department represented by the Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay, then applied to this Court and obtained special leave to appeal from the judgment and orders of the High Court of Bombay in the two References.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeals heard together, arising from similar facts.

anchor.surface_text: These two appeals with special leave have been heard together. They arise out of similar facts and the question of law arising therefrom is the same.

facts.text: Shares stood separately in the name of each of the three widows.

anchor.surface_text: On the companytrary, the statement of the case shows that the assessee filed lists of shares, companyies whereof are marked annexure C and form part of the case, which showed that the shares stood separately in the name of each one of the three widows and this was number denied by the Department.

facts.text: Widows entitled to equal share of income, one-third each.

anchor.surface_text: they are entitled as between themselves to an equal share of the income. Though they take as joint tenants, numberone of them has a right to enforce an absolute partition of the estate against the others so as to destroy their right of survivorship.

facts.text: Supreme Court held no finding of joint enterprise to produce income, widows not AOP.

anchor.surface_text: Coming back to the facts found by the Tribunal, there is numberfinding that the three widows have companybined in a joint enterprise to produce income. ... On these findings it cannot be held that the three widows had the status of an association of persons within the meaning of s. 3 of the Indian Income Tax Act.

facts.text: Appeals dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court companyrectly answered question No. 3 in the negative. Accordingly, the appeals fail and are dismissed with companyts.

facts.text: High Court judgment dated March 7, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 7, 1956, of the Bombay High Court in I.T.R. Nos. 52 and 53 of 1955.

facts.text: No appeal by Department against AAC finding on s.9(3) for immovable property.

anchor.surface_text: There was numberappeal by the Department against that finding and it was number 68 open to the Tribunal to go behind it.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on April 14, 1960 by K. DAS, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1960. April 14. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by K. DAS, J.-

s. 9 3  of the Income-tax Act, 1922. The Appellate Assistant Commissioner rejected point  a  but accepted point  b . Then, there was a further appeal to the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, Bombay.

They succeed as heirs to the estate of their deceased husband and take as joint tenants with rights of survivorship and equal beneficial enjoyment

There was no appeal by the Department

arguments.claim: No joint management re shares/dividends/interest; shares held separately in each widow's name

On the contrary, the statement of the case shows that the assessee filed lists of shares ... which showed that the shares stood separately in the name of each one of the three widows

arguments.claim: Association of persons requires two or more persons join in common purpose/action, object to produce income (plain meaning and precedents)

anchor.surface_text: Derbyshire, C. J., rightly pointed out that the word associate means ... to join in common purpose, or to join in an action. Therefore, an association of persons must be one in which two or more persons join in a common purpose or common action, and as the words occur in a section which imposes a tax on income

arguments.claim: No universal formula for AOP; depends on facts; appellant's common source test not determinative

anchor.surface_text: There is no formula of universal application as to what facts ... it must depend on the particular facts and circumstances of each case as to whether the conclusion can be drawn or not. ... we are of the view that the test suggested by learned counsel for the appellant are neither conclusive nor determinative

arguments.claim: On facts, no joint enterprise to produce income; widows not AOP under s.3

anchor.surface_text: Coming back to the facts found by the Tribunal, there is no finding that the three widows have combined in a joint enterprise to produce income. ... On these findings it cannot be held that the three widows had the status of an association of persons within the meaning of s. 3 of the Indian Income Tax Act.

holdings.text: The three widows had the status of an association of persons within the meaning of s. 3 of the Indian Income Tax Act is incorrect; they do not constitute an AOP.

anchor.surface_text: Coming back to the facts found by the Tribunal, there is no finding that the three widows have combined in a joint enterprise to produce income. ... On these findings it cannot be held that the three widows had the status of an association of persons within the meaning of s. 3 of the Indian Income Tax Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No Tribunal finding of joint enterprise to produce income; joint management/receipt of income from inherited estate insufficient; applies precedents requiring common purpose/action for income production.

holdings.text: An association of persons is one in which two or more persons join in a common purpose or common action, the object of which is to produce income, profits or gains.

anchor.surface_text: Derbyshire, C. J., rightly pointed out that the word associate means, according to the Oxford dictionary, to join in common purpose, or to join in an action. Therefore, an association of persons must be one in which two or more persons join in a common purpose or common action, and as the words occur in a section which imposes a tax on income,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain ordinary meaning of 'associate'; contextual interpretation in taxing section; adopts and affirms precedents (B.N. Elias, Laxmidas Devidas, Dwarakanath Pitale).

holdings.text: The aforesaid decisions correctly lay down the crucial test for determining what is an association of persons within the meaning of s. 3 of the Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: We think that the aforesaid decisions correctly lay down the crucial test for determining what is an association of persons within the meaning of s. 3 of the Income-tax Act, and they have been accepted and followed in a number of later decisions of different High Courts

holdings.reasoning_summary: Endorses prior High Court precedents as authoritative on AOP definition; no need for ejusdem generis analysis.

holdings.text: There is no formula of universal application to determine AOP; it must depend on the particular facts and circumstances of each case.

anchor.surface_text: There is no formula of universal application as to what facts, how many of them and of what nature, are necessary to come to a conclusion that there is an association of persons within the meaning of s. 3 it must depend on the particular facts and circumstances of each case

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects universal tests (e.g., common source); emphasizes fact-specific inquiry per precedents.

holdings.text: The respective shares of the widows were definite and ascertainable (one-third each); provisions of s. 9(3) clearly applied to the immovable property income.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, however, rightly pointed out that the only property which the widows could have managed jointly was the immovable property which fetched an income of about Rs. 11,000, and as to that property, the Appellate Assistant Commissioner had held that s. 9(3) applied. ... Even on merits the Tribunal was wrong in thinking that the respective shares of the widows were not definite and ascertainable. They had an equal share in the income, viz., one-third each,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Equal shares under Mitakshara law definite; AAC finding unappealed, binding on Tribunal; joint management limited to immovable property.

holdings.text: Tribunal not open to go behind AAC finding on s.9(3) as no appeal by Department.

anchor.surface_text: There was no appeal by the Department against that finding and it was not open to the Tribunal to go behind it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural bar: unappealed lower finding final.

holdings.text: Under Mitakshara law, widows succeed as joint tenants with rights of survivorship and equal beneficial enjoyment; entitled to equal income shares and partition for income enjoyment but not absolute partition destroying survivorship.

anchor.surface_text: They succeed as heirs to the estate of their deceased husband and take as joint tenants with rights of survivorship and equal beneficial enjoyment they are entitled as between themselves to an equal share of the income. Though they take as joint tenants, none of them has a right to enforce an absolute partition of the estate against the others so as to destroy their right of survivorship. But they are entitled to obtain a partition of separate portions of the property so that each may enjoy her equal share of the income accruing therefrom.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Well-settled position clears ground for AOP analysis; shares definite for s.9(3).

holdings.text: The High Court correctly answered question No. 3 in the negative; appeals fail and are dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court correctly answered question No. 3 in the negative. Accordingly, the appeals fail and are dismissed with costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirms HC reversal of Tribunal; applies AOP test to facts.

precedents.citation: In re B. N. Elias and Others  1

anchor.surface_text: It is enough for our purpose to refer to three decisions In re B. N. Elias and Others  1  Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay v. Laxmidas Devidas and Another   and In re Dwarakanath Harishchandra Pitale and Another 3  In In re N. Elias and Others  1  Derbyshire, C. J., rightly pointed out that the word associate means, according to the Oxford dictionary, to join in companymon purpose, or to join in an action. Therefore, an association of persons must be OD e in which two or more persons join in a companymon purpose or companymon action, and as the words occur in

precedents.case_name: In re B. N. Elias and Others
precedents.cited_proposition: word associate means to join in common purpose or common action; association of persons must be for producing income as per tax section
precedents.cited_holding: the word associate means, according to the Oxford dictionary, to join in companymon purpose, or to join in an action. Therefore, an association of persons must be OD e in which two or more persons join in a companymon purpose or companymon action, and as the words occur in a section which imposes a tax on income, the association must be one the object of which is to produce income, profits or gains.

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay v. Laxmidas Devidas and Another

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay v. Laxmidas Devidas and Another   and In re Dwarakanath Harishchandra Pitale and Another 3  In In re N. Elias and Others  1  Derbyshire, C. J., rightly pointed out that the word associate means, according to the Oxford dictionary, to join in companymon purpose, or to join in an action. Therefore, an association of persons must be OD e in which two or more persons join in a companymon purpose or companymon action, and as the words occur in a section which imposes a tax on income, the association must be one the object of which is to produce income, profits or gains. This was the view expressed by Beaumont, J., in Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay v. Laxmidas Devidas and Another  1  at page 589 and also in Re Dwarakanath Harishchandra Pitale and Another  2 .

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay v. Laxmidas Devidas and Another
precedents.cited_proposition: view that association of persons must join in common purpose or action to produce income

precedents.citation: In re Dwarakanath Harishchandra Pitale and Another 3

anchor.surface_text: and In re Dwarakanath Harishchandra Pitale and Another 3  In In re N. Elias and Others  1  Derbyshire, C. J., rightly pointed out that the word associate means, according to the Oxford dictionary, to join in companymon purpose, or to join in an action. Therefore, an association of persons must be OD e in which two or more persons join in a companymon purpose or companymon action, and as the words occur in a section which imposes a tax on income, the association must be one the object of which is to produce income, profits or gains. This was the view expressed by Beaumont, J., in Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay v. Laxmidas Devidas and Another  1  at page 589 and also in Re Dwarakanath Harishchandra Pitale and Another  2 . In re B. Elias  3   Costello, J., put the test in more force full language.

anchor.surface_text: This was the view expressed by Beaumont, J., in Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay v. Laxmidas Devidas and Another  1  at page 589 and also in Re Dwarakanath Harishchandra Pitale and Another  2 . In re B. Elias  3   Costello, J., put the test in more force full language. He said It may well be that the intention of the legislature was to hit companybinations of individuals who were engaged together in some joint enterprise but did number in law companystitute partnership When we find that there is a companybination of persons formed for the promotion of a joint enterprise then I think numberdifficulty arises in the way of saying that these persons did companystitute an association

precedents.cited_proposition: view expressed that association requires common purpose to produce income

precedents.citation: Re Dwarakanath Harishchandra Pitale and Another  2

anchor.surface_text: at page 589 and also in Re Dwarakanath Harishchandra Pitale and Another  2 . In re B. Elias  3   Costello, J., put the test in more force full language. He said It may well be that the intention of the legislature was to hit companybinations of individuals who were engaged together in some joint enterprise but did number in law companystitute partnership When we find that there is a companybination of persons formed for the promotion of a joint enterprise then I think numberdifficulty arises in the way of saying that these persons did companystitute an association We think that the aforesaid decisions companyrectly lay down the crucial test for determining what is an association of persons within the meaning of s. 3 of the Income-tax Act, and they have been accepted and followed in a number of later decisions of different High Courts to all of which it is unnecessary to call attention.

precedents.case_name: Re Dwarakanath Harishchandra Pitale and Another
precedents.cited_proposition: view that association requires common purpose to produce income

anchor.surface_text: In re B. Elias  3   Costello, J., put the test in more force full language. He said It may well be that the intention of the legislature was to hit companybinations of individuals who were engaged together in some joint enterprise but did number in law companystitute partnership When we find that there is a companybination of persons formed for the promotion of a joint enterprise then I think numberdifficulty arises in the way of saying that these persons did companystitute an association We think that the aforesaid decisions companyrectly lay down the crucial test for determining what is an association of persons within the meaning of s. 3 of the Income-tax Act, and they have been accepted and followed in a number of later decisions of different High Courts to all of which it is unnecessary to call attention. It is, however, necessary to add some words of caution here.

precedents.cited_proposition: test for association of persons: combination for joint enterprise none in law a partnership

anchor.surface_text: Coming back to the facts found by the Tribunal, there is no finding that the three widows have combined in a joint enterprise to produce income. ... On these findings it cannot be held that the three widows had the status of an association of persons within the meaning of s. 3 of the Indian Income Tax Act.

Coming back to the facts found by the Tribunal, there is no finding that the three widows have combined in a joint enterprise to produce income. ... On these findings it cannot be held that the three widows had the status of an association of persons within the meaning of s. 3 of the Indian Income Tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, however, rightly pointed out that the only property which the widows could have managed jointly was the immovable property which fetched an income of about Rs. 11,000, and as to that property, the Appellate Assistant Commissioner had held that s. 9(3) applied. ... Even on merits the Tribunal was wrong in thinking that the respective shares of the widows were not definite and ascertainable. They had an equal share in the income, viz., one-third each,

anchor.surface_text: There was no appeal by the Department against that finding and it was not open to the Tribunal to go behind it.
There was no appeal by the Department against that finding and it was not open to the Tribunal to go behind it.

They succeed as heirs to the estate of their deceased husband and take as joint tenants with rights of survivorship and equal beneficial enjoyment they are entitled as between themselves to an equal share of the income. Though they take as joint tenants, none of them has a right to enforce an absolute partition of the estate against the others so as to destroy their right of survivorship. But they are entitled to obtain a partition of separate portions of the property so that each may enjoy her equal share of the income accruing therefrom.
